journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Effects of nonconstant coupling through nonlinear magnetics in electromagnetic vibration energy harvesters

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Microsystems Engineering, University of Freiburg, Freiburg, Germany
2Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: Clemens Cepnik, Department of Microsystems Engineering, University of Freiburg, Georges-Köhler-Allee 102, Freiburg 79110, Germany. Email: Clemens.Cepnik@imtek.de

article-meta.issue-title: Special Topical Issue on Nonlinear Energy Harvesting

abstract.p: This article discusses how a nonhomogeneous magnetic field with a nonconstant flux gradient affects the behavior of electromagnetic vibration energy harvesters. Based on simulations, the authors show that this nonlinearity enables to increase the output power and bandwidth but not to effectively limit the oscillator vibration amplitude. The impact, however, depends on various system parameters, especially the mechanical damping. Comparing the results to an energy-harvesting prototype, one can conclude that, in practice, the linear model based on a homogeneous magnetic field provides a good estimate. The authors finally give suggestions about magnetic fields that are beneficial for energy harvesting.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Currently, probably the most important challenges in electromagnetic energy harvesting are how to gain high power from broadband vibration, how to increase the output voltage of miniaturized harvesters, and how to usefully limit the vibration amplitude of the oscillator for large excitations. In recent research, nonlinear effects have been utilized by different groups to find solutions for these challenges.

Nonlinear restoring forces through both nonlinear springs and magnetic forces have been applied to harvest from broadband vibration (Barton and Burrow, 2011; Barton et al., 2010; Challa et al., 2008; Karami and Inman, 2011; Mann and Sims, 2009; Nguyen and Halvorsen, 2010; Sasaki et al., 2005; Spreemann et al., 2006a, 2006b; Zhu et al., 2010). An advantage of designs (Challa et al., 2008; Mann and Sims, 2009; Spreemann et al., 2006a) with stiffening restoring forces, that is, the capability of storing more mechanical energy at a certain oscillator deflection, is that the oscillation amplitude can be limited for a wide range of excitation accelerations. A softening character of the restoring forces can create a bistable nonresonant system that is beneficial for harvesting from wideband and random vibrations (Barton and Burrow, 2011; Barton et al., 2010; Cottone et al., 2009; Mann and Owens, 2010). Superharmonic resonances at frequencies below the natural resonance can result in a frequency up-conversion with the oscillation frequency above the excitation frequency (Barton et al., 2010). On the one hand, this helps to harvest energy at an additional frequency range. On the other hand, the frequency up-conversion can be utilized to realize the same output power with a smaller oscillator displacement amplitude. With another chaotic system, namely, a pendulum oscillator, it was shown that under certain boundary conditions energy can be harvested in a broadband way while additionally the internal vibration amplitude is limited and excitation peaks are withstood by the bearing (Sasaki et al., 2005; Spreemann et al., 2006b). However, compared to the linear system in resonance, the improvements are at the expense of the maximum average output power at a single (resonance) frequency. With the help of high magnetic flux gradients, which imply nonlinear magnetic fields, the peak voltage and power have been maximized. The realized average power, however, was small (Xing et al., 2009). Sneller and Mann (2010) studied the nonlinear coupling between a permanent magnet and a coil in detail and introduced a set of analytic equations describing the voltage induction.

Similar to the study by Sneller and Mann (2010), we investigate nonlinear coupling due to nonhomogeneous magnetic fields of electromagnetic harvesters. We discuss not only the effect of nonlinear electromagnetic damping on the output voltage but also the system behavior of electromagnetic energy harvesters. This is of broader interest, because in reality, the nonlinear and respectively nonhomogeneous magnetic field of permanent magnets with or without back iron is the rule rather than the exception. Most articles imply the assumption that the maximum power is provided by a fully linear vibration harvester that is in harmonic oscillation at resonance. It stands to reason that vibration amplitudes are smaller when nonlinear springs are used. This can be demonstrated, for example, for a Duffing system, by normalizing results given in the study by Mann and Sims (2009). In contrast, with the help of simulations and analytical investigations, we will show that the velocity-dependent electromagnetic energy conversion is most effective for nonlinear systems with nonconstant flux gradients. Our study will provide the following:

list-item.p: An investigation into how the output power can be increased using nonlinear fields
An investigation of the possibility to limit the maximum deflection
An investigation of the validity to use the linear system equations to describe the behavior of a harvester with nonlinear fields
Comments on the practical importance for applications and implications for the design of harvesters of different size

sec.p: For our investigations, we model the electromagnetic energy harvester with varying magnetic flux distributions and boundary conditions in MATLAB Simulink. The harvester parameters are based on measurements of a prototype. We will provide evidence that the nonlinear magnetic fields that typically appear in practice are beneficial for electromagnetic vibration harvesters but of limited impact.

sec.p:

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p: The general input and model parameters are shown in Table 1. A sinusoidal excitation was applied. The parameters are based on the cylindrical prototype we introduced in the study by Cepnik et al. (2011) (see Figure 3).

caption.p:
Exemplary harvester designs and the flux density with respect to the relative displacement

sec.p:
The applied flux density functions
B
⊥
( x )
are rooted in four exemplary harvester designs including the cylindrical prototypes. The designs feature different flux gradient distributions as plotted in Figure 3. The maximum flux gradient of flux density is typically either around zero crossing or at maximum deflection. In out model we use an empirically derived parametrization to account for these typical distributions.

Figure 4 gives an overview of the different flux gradients according to equation (4). They were found with the constant load attach × ed that provides maximum power (see section “Output power with respect to flux density distribution”). The parameter

sec.p:
This normalization is due to the assumption that the total flux that can be generated by magnets within a certain harvester volume and hence the possible change of flux are limited. Indeed, other normalizations are possible. For example, assuming a certain average
B
⊥

B
⊥
( x )
. A different penetrated volume in principle allows using more or less of the total volume for the magnetic circuit. However, in most cases, the vibration amplitude is small compared to the harvester height, and hence, the first normalization approach still seems to be beneficial. Also, selected simulations show that the phenomena discussed in this article appear similarly for a normalization with respect to the average flux gradient. Finally, the normalization does not account for the fact that realizing different
B
⊥
( x )
in practice requires designs of different complexity and volume. The extremum flux gradients with peak values of much more than

sec.title: Dynamic behavior
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows that although the vibration amplitude can be influenced by
B
⊥
( x )
, the nonconstant gradient does little help to limit the amplitude. Compared to the linear case, one could, of course, reduce the output amplitude by attaching a smaller load resistance. The increased electrical current would result in a larger electrical damping. However, the trade-off would be a lower output power.

The nonsignificant impact of the flux distribution curve on the displacement amplitude becomes obvious in Figure 13, which shows the displacement–velocity curve for different mechanical damping values
d
m
and the most extreme flux gradient distributions (at the optimum load for each parameter set). For small
d
m
, the curve is a circle, which means that the mechanical damping does not visibly effect the sinusoidal motion of the oscillator, and the inertial force is much larger than the damping force. In contrast, for higher mechanical damping, the energy transfer becomes visible, and the electrical damping force causes a cut in the graph resulting in a visibly nonsinusoidal oscillation. Remembering the mechanical damping of
0 . 3
N / ( m
s
− 1
)
that was measured for our cylindrical harvester, we can conclude that in practice, the motion curve is little influenced by the flux density distribution.

sec.title: Conclusion and practical impact
sec.p: From our simulations and analytical investigations, we can conclude the following:

list-item.p: Nonhomogeneous magnetic fields featuring nonconstant flux gradients can provide higher output power compared to homogeneous fields. We found that gradients with a strong maximum at zero deflection of the oscillator provide highest output power. Even for gradient distributions with their maxima at maximum oscillator deflection, higher power can be achieved. This phenomenon is important for the harvester design, because magnetic fields in practice are not homogeneous and can potentially be optimized.

A higher flux gradient at zero crossing and smaller gradient for increasing displacement of the oscillator will enable to increase the bandwidth. However, this increase is modest and other approaches are more beneficial to achieve broadband vibration harvesting.

Compared to the linear case, a high flux gradient at zero crossing of the oscillator helps to provide higher output power both in case the excitation acceleration drops or increases. For a large range of input accelerations, however, the load has to be adapted.

Lower mechanical damping reduces the significance of the flux gradient. In fact, the significance does also depend on the volume of the coil and the oscillator mass. Thus, in case of microharvesters featuring not only low damping but also a small volume, the flux gradient distribution can have a large impact. Although the limited degree of freedom in microfabrication suggests the use of a simple design, it can be very important to focus on the design optimization of the magnetic circuit and the inductor.

The resistance match that is valid for linear systems (equation (12)) does not apply to the nonlinear system. Better results can be achieved with a matched constant load. Although there might exist a better impedance match, the simple way of using a constant load will give good results.

The flux gradient distribution has only a small impact on the motion of the oscillator. It seems not to be useful to limit the displacement amplitude using a certain gradient. Therefore, other approaches like nonlinear springs should be used to limit the maximum displacement and prevent the oscillator from touching the housing and the springs from overstressing.

The flux gradient distribution has very limited effect on the sinusoidal shape of the motion. Only for very high mechanical damping, the impact of a nonconstant flux gradient becomes apparent. Therefore, for the nonlinear model and the parameter sets used in this article, the linear system equations provide a good estimate.

sec.p:
The results show that the magnetic flux distributions one can find in practice can beneficially be utilized to harvest higher power. Especially facing strong fabrication restrictions, as, for example, in microtechnologies, knowledge about the impact of nonlinear gradients can be very helpful. The rule of thumb is to design for high flux gradients at zero crossing of the oscillator. However, as can be concluded from section “Boundary conditions,” flux gradients that can be realized in practice usually only feature small slew rates. Therefore, the impact of the flux gradient distribution in practice is limited. Output power in resonance can be effected by approximately
5 % − 10 %
and bandwidth by
10 % − 30 %
, both decreasing for macroscopic harvesters and increasing for miniaturized harvesters. We can conclude that it is more important to realize a strong change of flux than a certain flux distribution.

The phenomena discussed cannot be directly applied to the piezoelectric and electrostatic harvesting principles. While the electromagnetic energy conversion is a velocity-dependent mechanism, these two depend on static variables, that is, displacement and tension.
